els.title: Gulf Stream
els.text: This fast-moving current carries a significant proportion of ocean heat from the tropics to the Arctic.

els.title: Kuroshio Current
els.text: A warm current running north from the tropics. In the mid-latitudes, it joins the North Pacific current and flows eastward.

els.title: Southern Ocean
els.text: Powerful eastward winds drive the surface currents circling Antarctica.

els.title: Southern Ocean
els.text: Powerful eastward winds drive the surface currents circling Antarctica.

els.title: Northern Polar Front
els.text: Cold, westward flowing polar air encounters the warmer, eastward flowing air of the mid-latitudes to create a belt of unstable, sometimes stormy weather.

els.title: Trade Winds
els.text: In the age of sailing ships, sailors used these steady winds to navigate the globe. These surface winds blow southwest in the Northern Hemisphere and northwest the Southern Hemisphere toward the equator.

els.title: Coriolis Effect
els.text: The process by which Earthâ€™s rotation deflects the flow of water or air to the right in the Northern Hemisphere and left in the Southern Hemisphere when facing the direction of movement. The Coriolis effect accounts for the westerly component of the trade winds.

els.title: Hadley cells
els.text: Warm air rises from the equator, then cools as it moves toward the poles. This cool air sinks to the surface, creating a loop of air circulation known as a Hadley cell.

els.title: Thermal Equator
els.text: This band of warm air rises from where solar energy is most concentrated. This changes seasonally, moving slightly north in June and south in December.

els.title: Thermal Equator
els.text: This band of warm air rises from where solar energy is most concentrated. This changes seasonally, moving slightly north in June and south in December.
